Knowledge Point: Moloko has two kinds of transitive clauses -- transitive clauses with subject and direct object (\ref{ex:9:1}--\ref{ex:9:2}) and transitive clauses with subject and indirect object (\ref{ex:9:3}--\ref{ex:9:4}). These two grammatically different transitive clauses illustrate that the semantics of Moloko verbs allows three core participants (represented by subject, direct object, and indirect object). Moloko verbs do not have just Agent-Patient semantic frames for events. In this work we follow an Agent-Theme-Location analysis, as developed by \citet{DeLancey1991}, in which ‘Location’ (\LOC) has a particular definition. Indirect object always expresses semantic {\LOC} -- the participant that represents the place where the Theme is directed to. As such the indirect object can express (depending on the verb type, see Sections~\ref{sec:9.2.3}--\ref{sec:9.2.5}) the recipient or beneficiary of the event. Direct object always expresses semantic Theme, the core participant that changes position or state because of the event. Subject in transitive clauses expresses the Agent.
Content 1: \gsrc Mana aslay awak. | \gll Mana a-ɬ-aj awak | \gls Mana 3S-slay-CL goat | \glt ‘Mana slays a goat.’

Knowledge Point: Examples \REF{ex:9:1} and \REF{ex:9:2} show a transitive clause with subject (Mana) and direct object (awak ‘goat’ in \ref{ex:9:1}, na \oldstylenums{3}\textsc{s} direct object pronominal in \ref{ex:9:2}).
Content 1: \gsrc Mana aslay awak. | \gll Mana a-ɬ-aj awak | \gls Mana 3S-slay-CL goat | \glt ‘Mana slays a goat.’
Content 3: \gsrc Mana aslay awak. | \gll Mana a-ɬ-aj awak | \gls Mana 3S-slay-CL goat | \glt ‘Mana slays a goat.’

Knowledge Point: Examples \REF{ex:9:3} and \REF{ex:9:4} show a transitive clause with subject (Mana) and indirect object (ana kəra ‘to dog’ in \ref{ex:9:3}, =an ‘to him’ in \ref{ex:9:4}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Returning to the transitive clause with subject and direct object (\ref{ex:9:1} and \ref{ex:9:2}), the direct object awak ‘goat’ is the Theme -- the participant that changes position or state because of an event (it is slain).
Content 1: \gsrc Mana aslay awak. | \gll Mana a-ɬ-aj awak | \gls Mana 3S-slay-CL goat | \glt ‘Mana slays a goat.’

Subsection: Group 1: Verbs that can only be intransitive\label{sec:9.2.1\is{Tense, mood, and aspect!Progressive|(
Knowledge Point: Only one verb in Moloko can never take an object (neither direct nor indirect). The locational clause contains the verb nday. It states that the subject is presently located somewhere (\ref{ex:9:5}--\ref{ex:9:6}). An explicit free noun phrase subject is not required when this verb is the main predicate since the subject is indicated in the verb prefix; however an adpositional phrase giving the location is required and follows the verb. This same verb functions as a progressive aspect auxiliary (see \sectref{sec:8.2.1}).\footnote{It is interesting that the locational extension =aka is also used to express progressive aspect \sectref{sec:7.5.1}.}
Content 1: \gsrc Hawa \textbf{anday} a mogom. | \gll Hawa \textbf{a-ndaj} a mɔgʷɔm | \gls Hawa {3S-be.located at home | \glt ‘Hawa is at home.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Anday} a Marva. | \gll \textbf{a-ndaj} a marva | \gls 3S-be at Maroua | \glt ‘She is in Maroua.’

Subsection: Group 2: Verbs that can be transitive with direct object\label{sec:9.2.2
Knowledge Point: Verbs from this class express reflexive actions when in an intransitive clause (action is to self; \ref{ex:9:7}) and causative actions when in a transitive clause with a direct object (action is to direct object; \ref{ex:9:8}).
Content 1: Not found

Subsection: Group 3: Verbs that can be transitive with indirect object\label{sec:9.2.3\is{Attribution!Expressed using verb
Knowledge Point: The verb rəɓ-ay ‘to be beautiful’ involves a thing and its quality (\ref{ex:9:9}--\ref{ex:9:10}), and the person whose opinion or perception is being cited is coded as the indirect object. In an intransitive clause, the subject (dalay ‘girl’) is at the state of being beautiful. In a transitive clause (with an indirect object), the subject (dalay ‘girl’) is felt to be beautiful by the indirect object (=aw ‘to me’).
Content 1: Not found

Subsection: Group 3: Verbs that can be transitive with indirect object\label{sec:9.2.3\is{Attribution!Expressed using verb
Knowledge Point: The experience verb /ts r/ ‘taste good’ is grammatically expressed in \REF{ex:9:11} as the subject ɗaf ‘millet loaf' tastes good to the semantic \LOC expressed by the indirect object (the pronominal enclitic =aw ‘to me’).
Content 1: Not found

Subsection: Group 3: Verbs that can be transitive with indirect object\label{sec:9.2.3\is{Attribution!Expressed using verb
Knowledge Point: Likewise with the verb /g r -j/ ‘fear’ \REF{ex:9:12}, the elephant causes fear at the \LOC ‘the children.’
Content 1: Not found

Subsection: Group 3: Verbs that can be transitive with indirect object\label{sec:9.2.3\is{Attribution!Expressed using verb
Knowledge Point: Note that an intransitive clause appears to be ungrammatical for the verbs \newline/ɓ-j/ ‘hit’ and /s/ ‘please’ (\ref{ex:9:13}--\ref{ex:9:14}).
Content 1: Not found

Subsection: Group 4: Verbs that can be bitransitive\label{sec:9.2.4
Knowledge Point: The verb p-ay ‘open’ illustrates this verb type. In a transitive clause \REF{ex:9:15}, the subject (Mana) performs the action on the direct object (mahay ‘door’).
Content 1: \gsrc Mana apay mahay. | \gll Mana à-p-aj mahaj | \gls Mana 3S+PFV-open-CL door | \glt ‘He/she opened the door.’

Subsection: Group 4: Verbs that can be bitransitive\label{sec:9.2.4
Knowledge Point: In a bitransitive clause \REF{ex:9:16}, the action done to the direct object is for the benefit of the indirect object.
Content 1: \gsrc Mana apan mahay ana Hawa. | \gll Mana à-p=aŋ mahaj ana Hawa | \gls Mana 3S+PFV-open=3S.IO door DAT Hawa | \glt ‘Mana opened the door for Hawa.’

Subsection: Group 4: Verbs that can be bitransitive\label{sec:9.2.4
Knowledge Point: The verb mənjar ‘see’ occurs in intransitive, transitive, and bitransitive clauses. In a transitive clause \REF{ex:9:17}, the subject (Mala) sees the direct object (awak ‘goat’).\footnote{The indirect object ‘goat’ undergoes a change of state from being unseen to being seen at a particular \LOC.}
Content 1: \gsrc Mala ámənjar awak. | \gll Mala á-mənzar awak | \gls Mala 3S+IFV-see goat | \glt ‘Mala sees a goat.’{ }

Subsection: Group 4: Verbs that can be bitransitive\label{sec:9.2.4
Knowledge Point: In a bitransitive clause \REF{ex:9:18}, the subject (Mala) sees the direct object (awak ‘goat’) on behalf of the indirect object beneficiary (bahay ‘chief’). The chief is the metaphorical \LOC to which the action is directed.
Content 1: \gsrc Mala olo amənjaran awak ana bahay. | \gll Mala ɔ-lɔ a-mənzar=aŋ awak ana bahaj | \gls Mala 3S-go 3S-see=3S.IO goat DAT chief | \glt ‘Mala went to see a person’s goat in the chief’s place.’{ }

Subsection: Group 4: Verbs that can be bitransitive\label{sec:9.2.4
Knowledge Point: For the verb /h/ ‘say’ \REF{ex:9:19}, the subject Mana says the utterance (expressed by the direct object pronominal na) to Hawa.
Content 1: \gsrc Mana ahan na ana Hawa. | \gll Mana à-h=aŋ na ana Hawa | \gls Mana 3S+PFV-say=3S.IO 3S.DO DAT Hawa | \glt ‘Mana told it to Hawa.’

Subsection: Group 4: Verbs that can be bitransitive\label{sec:9.2.4
Knowledge Point: For some transitive verbs of this type, the indirect object (when present) marks the malefactive of the event. The indirect object will be negatively affected by the event. For the verb paɗ-ay ‘eat’ in \REF{ex:9:20} the subject (awak ‘goat’) ate the direct object (háy ‘millet’), incurring a negative effect on the indirect object (=aw ‘to me’).\footnote{This phenomenon is also known as possessor raising or external possession. We consider that the semantics for this construction in Moloko are malefactive rather than possessive because a possessive construction can also be employed (without an indirect object): awak a-paɗ-ay na háy əwla =va, ‘the goat ate my millet’. The construction with an indirect object connects the millet to its owner with less precision than the possessive construction, and concentrates on the loss that the owner incurred (due to the damages done to his millet field) rather than the fact that he owned the field.}
Content 1: \gsrc Awak apaɗ\textbf{aw} na háy va. | \gll awak a-paɗ\textbf{=aw} na haj=va | \gls goat 3S-crunch=oneS.IO 3S.DO millet=PRF | \glt ‘The goat has eaten my millet.’ (lit. the goat has eaten to me the millet)

Subsection: Group 4: Verbs that can be bitransitive\label{sec:9.2.4
Knowledge Point: The indirect object also expresses the malefactive with the verbs mbəzen ‘ruin’ \REF{ex:9:21} and cen ‘understand’ \REF{ex:9:22}. In \REF{ex:9:21} the subject (sla=ahay ‘the cows’) have ruined the direct object (gəvah ‘the field’) with a negative effect on the indirect object (=aloko ‘to us’).
Content 1: \gsrc Sla ahaj təmbəzaloko na gəvah va. | \gll ɬa=ahaj t\'{ə}-mbəz=alɔkʷɔ na gəvah=va | \gls cow=Pl 3P+PFV-ruin=1PIN.IO 3S.DO field=PRF | \glt ‘The cows have ruined our field.’ (lit. The cows have ruined to us the field)
Content 2: \gsrc Acaw aka va ma əwla bay. | \gll à-ts=aw =aka=va ma=uwla baj | \gls 3S+PFV-understand=oneS.IO =on=PRF word=oneS.POSS NEG | \glt ‘He/she didn’t understand my words.’ (lit. he had understood on my words not)
Content 3: \gsrc Sla ahaj təmbəzaloko na gəvah va. | \gll ɬa=ahaj t\'{ə}-mbəz=alɔkʷɔ na gəvah=va | \gls cow=Pl 3P+PFV-ruin=1PIN.IO 3S.DO field=PRF | \glt ‘The cows have ruined our field.’ (lit. The cows have ruined to us the field)

Subsection: Group 4: Verbs that can be bitransitive\label{sec:9.2.4
Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:9:22} shows a bitransitive clause with the verb cen ‘hear’/'understand.' The subject (a- \oldstylenums{3}\textsc{s} subject pronominal) didn’t understand the direct object (ma =əwla ‘my words’) with a negative effect on the indirect object (=aw ‘to me’).\footnote{Note that phonetically the word-final /n/ drops off when the indirect object clitic attaches.}
Content 1: \gsrc Acaw aka va ma əwla bay. | \gll à-ts=aw =aka=va ma=uwla baj | \gls 3S+PFV-understand=oneS.IO =on=PRF word=oneS.POSS NEG | \glt ‘He/she didn’t understand my words.’ (lit. he had understood on my words not)

Subsection: Group 4: Verbs that can be bitransitive\label{sec:9.2.4
Knowledge Point: Moloko uses a transitive clause with a third person plural subject pronominal when the identity of the Agent is unimportant or unknown in the discourse. The literal meaning of \REF{ex:9:23} is ‘They are greeting you,’ but this construction is used even when the person greeting is singular and the speaker knows who it is but doesn’t want to say.\footnote{The verb /h-j/ ‘say’ shows incorporation of the ‘body-part’ noun ma ‘word/mouth’ (\sectref{sec:9.3}).} Example \REF{ex:9:24} is from the Disobedient Girl text (see \sectref{sec:1.5}). The example literally means ‘they brought her out’ but the identity of those who carried her is unimportant in the story.
Content 1: \gsrc Tahok ma. | \gll ta-h=ɔkʷ ma | \gls 3P-tell=twoS.IO mouth | \glt ‘You are being greeted.’ (lit. they are telling word to you)

Subsection: Group 4: Verbs that can be bitransitive\label{sec:9.2.4
Knowledge Point: There are two semantic possibilities for intransitive clauses of Group 4 verbs in Perfective aspect\is{Tense, mood, and aspect!Perfective aspect}\is{Tense, mood, and aspect!Aspect in intransitive clauses}. Subject can be the semantic Agent or the semantic Theme. Some verbs have both possibilities, but for other verbs, subject can express only Agent or only Theme. For the verb d-e ‘prepare,’ the subject of an intransitive clause is the semantic Agent \REF{ex:9:25} and the semantic Theme is unspecified.
Content 1: Not found

Subsection: Group 4: Verbs that can be bitransitive\label{sec:9.2.4
Knowledge Point: With cen ‘hear,’ an intransitive clause in Perfective aspect\is{Tense, mood, and aspect!Perfective aspect} \REF{ex:9:26} expresses an event where the subject hears and understands (what they hear/understand may not be explicit in the clause).
Content 1: Not found

Subsection: Group 4: Verbs that can be bitransitive\label{sec:9.2.4
Knowledge Point: In contrast, for the verb p-ay ‘open,’ the subject of an intransitive clause is the semantic Theme which is affected by the action \REF{ex:9:27}. More examples are shown in \tabref{tab:74}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mahay apay. | \gll mahaj à-p-aj | \gls door 3S+PFV-open-CL | \glt ‘The door opened.’

Subsection: Group 4: Verbs that can be bitransitive\label{sec:9.2.4
Knowledge Point: There is also a difference between the Imperfective\is{Tense, mood, and aspect!Imperfective aspect|(}, Perfective, and Perfect in an intransitive clause\is{Tense, mood, and aspect!Perfect|(} that doesn’t hold for transitive and bitransitive clauses.\is{Tense, mood, and aspect!Perfective aspect}\footnote{Intransitive clauses with transfer verbs \sectref{sec:9.2.5} also show this semantic picture.} In intransitive clauses for these verbs, Imperfective aspect indicates that the subject is at the state of being potentially able to do or submit to the action (more of an irrealis idea) while Perfect is a resultative state. In contrast, for transitive and bitransitive clauses, Imperfective aspect expresses an incomplete event (see \sectref{sec:7.4.2}) and the Perfect expresses that the event was completed prior to a point of reference (see \sectref{sec:7.5.3}). For example, an intransitive clause with the verb /p -j/ ‘open’ expresses an event with an unspecified Agent when the verb is Perfective: ‘the door opened’ \REF{ex:9:28}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mahay apay. | \gll mahaj à-p-aj | \gls door 3S+PFV-open-CL | \glt ‘The door opened.’

Subsection: Group 4: Verbs that can be bitransitive\label{sec:9.2.4
Knowledge Point: Likewise with the verb /b h/ ‘pour,’ water ‘is poured’ \REF{ex:9:29}.
Content 1: \gsrc Yam abah. | \gll jam à-bax | \gls water 3S+PFV-pour | \glt ‘Water poured.’

Subsection: Group 4: Verbs that can be bitransitive\label{sec:9.2.4
Knowledge Point: If the verb is Imperfective, the clause means that the door is able to be opened, i.e., it is not locked \REF{ex:9:30}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mahay ápay. | \gll mahaj á-p-aj | \gls door 3S+IFV-open-CL | \glt ‘The door opens.’

Subsection: Group 4: Verbs that can be bitransitive\label{sec:9.2.4
Knowledge Point: In the Perfect, the clause means that the door is open (i.e., someone has already opened it, \ref{ex:9:31}).
Content 1: \gsrc Mahay apava. | \gll mahaj a-pa=va | \gls door 3S-open=PRF | \glt ‘The door is open.’

Subsection: Group 4: Verbs that can be bitransitive\label{sec:9.2.4
Knowledge Point: aspect in an intransitive clause presents a situation where a state or capability is expressed. For the verb mənjar ‘see,’ an intransitive clause in Imperfective aspect \REF{ex:9:32} can have an abilitative sense in that the subject Mala is able to see. It can also mean that the subject is visible (subject expresses semantic Theme).
Content 1: Not found

Subsection: Group 5: Transfer verbs\label{sec:9.2.5
Knowledge Point: The verb vəl ‘give’ is shown in a bitransitive clause in \REF{ex:9:33}. The subject (bahay ‘chief’) transfers the direct object (dalay ‘girl’) to the indirect object (Mana).
Content 1: \gsrc Bahay avəlan dalay ana Mana. | \gll bahaj à-vəl=aŋ dalaj ana Mana | \gls chief 3S+PFV-give=3S.IO girl DAT Mana | \glt ‘The chief gave the girl to Mana (in marriage).’

Subsection: Group 5: Transfer verbs\label{sec:9.2.5
Knowledge Point: When vəl ‘give’ occurs in a transitive clause, the second core argument can be either a direct object \REF{ex:9:34} or an indirect object \REF{ex:9:35}. In \REF{ex:9:34}, the chief is marrying off his daughter to an unspecified suitor. The subject (bahay ‘chief’) transfers the direct object (dalay ‘girl’) to someone who is unspecified in the clause.
Content 1: \gsrc Bahay ávar dalay. | \gll bahaj á-var dalaj | \gls chief 3S+IFV-give girl | \glt ‘The chief is marrying off his daughter [to someone].’ (lit. chief gives girl)
Content 2: \gsrc Bahay avəlan ana Mana. | \gll bahaj à-vəl=aŋ ana Mana | \gls chief 3S+PFV-give=3S.IO DAT Mana | \glt ‘The chief gave [something] to Mana.’
Content 3: \gsrc Bahay ávar dalay. | \gll bahaj á-var dalaj | \gls chief 3S+IFV-give girl | \glt ‘The chief is marrying off his daughter [to someone].’ (lit. chief gives girl)

Subsection: Group 5: Transfer verbs\label{sec:9.2.5
Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:9:35}, the subject (bahay ‘chief’) transfers something or someone to the indirect object (Mana). What he gave would probably be specified in the immediate context, but is out of sight in this clause.
Content 1: \gsrc Bahay avəlan ana Mana. | \gll bahaj à-vəl=aŋ ana Mana | \gls chief 3S+PFV-give=3S.IO DAT Mana | \glt ‘The chief gave [something] to Mana.’

Subsection: Group 5: Transfer verbs\label{sec:9.2.5
Knowledge Point: When the verb vəl ‘give’ occurs in an intransitive negative clause (Imperfective\is{Tense, mood, and aspect!Imperfective aspect}, \ref{ex:9:36}), it expresses that the subject is in the state of not giving anything to anyone, or not being the giving kind.\footnote{Note the phonological change of the final consonant (r becomes l when there is a suffix, see \sectref{sec:6.2}). } Without the negative marker, the meaning would probably be ‘the chief is the giving kind.’\footnote{This is a specific example from a text. We have not seen one-participant clauses for this verb type in Perfective aspect. %%\is{Tense, mood, and aspect!Perfective aspect}
Content 1: \gsrc Bahay ávar bay. | \gll bahaj á-var baj | \gls chief 3S+IFV-give NEG | \glt ‘The chief is not the giving kind.’ (lit. chief doesn’t give)

Subsection: Group 5: Transfer verbs\label{sec:9.2.5
Knowledge Point: The verb dəbənay ‘learn’/‘teach’ occurs in transitive and bitransitive clauses.\footnote{We found no clauses with one core participant for this verb. } In bitransitive clauses illustrated by \REF{ex:9:37}, the subject (bahay ‘chief’) transfers the direct object (Məloko ‘Moloko language’) to the indirect object (ana babəza ahay ‘to the children’).\footnote{The indirect object is expressed in an adpositional phrase as well as the verbal pronominal extension =ata ‘to them.’ The indirect object expresses the recipient or beneficiary of the event.}
Content 1: Not found

Subsection: Group 5: Transfer verbs\label{sec:9.2.5
Knowledge Point: In transitive clauses with subject and direct object \REF{ex:9:38}, the subject (babəza ahay ‘children’) transfers the direct object (Məloko ‘Moloko language’) to self.
Content 1: \gsrc Babəza ahay tədəbənay Məloko. | \gll babəza=ahaj tə-dəbən-aj Mʊlɔkʷɔ | \gls children=Pl 3P-learn-CL Moloko | \glt ‘The children learn Moloko.’

Subsection: Group 5: Transfer verbs\label{sec:9.2.5
Knowledge Point: \REF{ex:9:39} illustrates a transitive clause with subject and indirect object. The subject (Məloko ‘Moloko language;’ the semantic Theme) is transferred to the indirect object (=ok ‘to you’).
Content 1: \gsrc Məloko adəbənok na jajak. | \gll Mʊlɔkʷɔ a-dəbən=ɔkʷ na dzadzak | \gls Moloko 3S-learn=twoS.IO PSP fast | \glt ‘Moloko is easy for you to learn.’ (lit. Moloko learns to you quickly)

Subsection: Group 5: Transfer verbs\label{sec:9.2.5
Knowledge Point: The verb skom ‘buy’/‘sell’ is also a transfer verb with two semantic {\scshape loc}s. The event of buy/sell is accomplished through transfer of the Theme from one \LOC to another. In a bitransitive clause \REF{ex:9:40}, the subject (nə- ‘I’) causes the direct object (awak ‘goat’) to go to the indirect object (ana Mana ‘to Mana’).
Content 1: \gsrc Nəskoman awak ana Mana. | \gll nə-sʊkʷɔm=aŋ awak ana Mana | \gls oneS-buy/sell=3S.IO goat DAT Mana | \glt ‘I sell a goat to Mana.’

Subsection: Group 5: Transfer verbs\label{sec:9.2.5
Knowledge Point: In a transitive clause with direct object \REF{ex:9:41}, the subject (nə- ‘I’) transfers the direct object (awak ‘goat’) to self. We found no intransitive clauses for this verb.
Content 1: \gsrc Nəskomala awak. | \gll nə-sʊkʷɔm=ala awak | \gls oneS-buy/sell=to goat | \glt ‘I bought a goat.’

Subsection: Group 5: Transfer verbs\label{sec:9.2.5
Knowledge Point: The verb hay ‘speak’ also appears to be in this class, but we have not found this verb in all contexts. In \REF{ex:9:42}, Mana caused what he said (na ‘it’) to go to the men.
Content 1: \gsrc Mana ahata na va ana zawər ahay. | \gll Mana à-h=ata na=va ana zawər=ahaj | \gls Mana 3S+PFV-speak=3P.IO 3S.DO=PRF DAT men=Pl | \glt ‘Mana has already told it to the men.’

Subsection: Group 5: Transfer verbs\label{sec:9.2.5
Knowledge Point: A fourth participant is possible for the verb vəl ‘give’ and appears as an oblique adjunct. When there is both a Beneficiary and a Recipient (which is the core \LOC), a preposition (kəla) plus one of the possessive pronouns (see \sectref{sec:3.1.2}) mark the benefactive. In \REF{ex:9:43} the subject (‘you,’ {\twoS} imperative verb) transfers the direct object (dala ‘money’) to the indirect object (=an ‘to him' and ana Mana ‘to Mana’) for the benefit of the person expressed by a possessive pronoun in the oblique prepositional phrase (kəla əwla ‘my benefit,’ bolded in the examples).
Content 1: Not found

Subsection: Group 5: Transfer verbs\label{sec:9.2.5
Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:9:44} the subject pronominal (a- ‘\oldstylenums{3}\textsc{s}’) transfers the direct object (awak ‘goat’) to the indirect object (pronominal enclitic =ok ‘to you’) for the benefit of the pronoun in the oblique (kəla =əwla ‘my benefit’).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: \citet{FriesenMamalis2008} identified a unique group of verb constructions in Moloko. In these constructions, a special, sometimes phonologically reduced noun form that represents a part of the body is incorporated into the verb phrase. This is a case of noun incorporation where these body-part nouns are closely associated with the verb complex and their incorporation changes the lexical characteristics of the verb. These body-part nouns include ma ‘mouth,’ (\ref{ex:9:45}, \sectref{sec:9.3.1.3}), elé ‘eye,’ (\ref{ex:9:46}, \sectref{sec:9.3.1.1}), sləmay ‘ear,’ (\ref{ex:9:47}, \sectref{sec:9.3.1.2}), and va or har ‘body,’ (\ref{ex:9:48}, \ref{ex:9:49}, Sections~\ref{sec:9.3.1.4} and \ref{sec:9.3.1.5}, respectively). These nouns can be incorporated into transitive or bitransitive verbs from the types in Sections~\ref{sec:9.2.2} and \ref{sec:9.2.3}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ataraŋ aka \textbf{ma} ana war ese. | \gll a-tar=aŋ =aka \textbf{ma} ana war ɛʃɛ | \gls 3S-call=3S.IO =on mouth DAT child again | \glt ‘He/she calls the child again.’ (lit. he calls mouth to him to the child again)
Content 2: \gsrc Mala amənjar \textbf{elé.} | \gll Mala a-mənzar \textbf{ɛlɛ} | \gls Mala 3S-see eye | \glt ‘Mala looks around attentively.’
Content 3: \gsrc Acaka va \textbf{sləmay} ana mama ahan bay. | \gll a-ts=aka=va \textbf{ɬəmaj} ana mama=ahaŋ baj | \gls 3S-hear=on=PRF ear DAT mother=3S.POSS NEG | \glt ‘He/she is disobedient to his mother.’ (he disobeys his mother)\footnote{Note that the word-final /n/ is deleted on the root /ts n\textsuperscript{e}/when the verbal extension is attached \sectref{sec:2.6.1}.}
Content 4: \gsrc Tandalay talala təzləge \textbf{va} ana Məloko ahay. | \gll ta-ndalaj ta-l=ala tɪ-ɮɪg-ɛ \textbf{va} ana Mʊlɔkʷɔ=ahaj | \gls 3P-PRG 3P-go=to 3P-throw-CL body DAT Moloko=Pl | \glt ‘They were coming and fighting with the Molokos.’ (lit. they were coming they threw body to Molokos)
Content 5: \gsrc Ma ango agəsaw \textbf{har}. | \gll ma=aŋgʷɔ a-gəs=aw \textbf{har} | \gls word=twoS.POSS 3S-catch=oneS.IO body | \glt ‘It pleases me.’ (lit. it catches body to me)

Knowledge Point: The body-part noun follows directly after all other elements in the verb complex. It appears to be in the same position as any other noun phrase direct object in the verb phrase (see \chapref{chap:8}); however it is in more tightly bound to the verb complex than a noun phrase. The body-part noun does not fill the \DO pronominal slot, because verbal extensions that follow the \DO pronominal in the Moloko verb complex precede the body-part (see \ref{ex:9:45} and \ref{ex:9:47} which each have an adpositional extension, see \sectref{sec:7.5.1}). It is not phonologically bound to the verb since, unlike the Perfect verbal extension =va which is part of the verb complex, the body-part va does not neutralise the prosody on the verb stem \REF{ex:9:48}. However, the incorporated noun is grammatically closer to the verb complex than a noun phrase direct object would be because the body-part can never be separated from the verb complex. The body-part can never be fronted in the clause (see \sectref{sec:8.1}). Nor can the body-part be separated from the verb complex by the presupposition marker. Both of these situations can occur for noun phrase direct objects and are illustrated in \sectref{sec:11.2} (\ref{ex:9:29} and \ref{ex:9:30}).
Content 1: \gsrc Ataraŋ aka \textbf{ma} ana war ese. | \gll a-tar=aŋ =aka \textbf{ma} ana war ɛʃɛ | \gls 3S-call=3S.IO =on mouth DAT child again | \glt ‘He/she calls the child again.’ (lit. he calls mouth to him to the child again)
Content 2: \gsrc Acaka va \textbf{sləmay} ana mama ahan bay. | \gll a-ts=aka=va \textbf{ɬəmaj} ana mama=ahaŋ baj | \gls 3S-hear=on=PRF ear DAT mother=3S.POSS NEG | \glt ‘He/she is disobedient to his mother.’ (he disobeys his mother)\footnote{Note that the word-final /n/ is deleted on the root /ts n\textsuperscript{e}/when the verbal extension is attached \sectref{sec:2.6.1}.}
Content 3: \gsrc Tandalay talala təzləge \textbf{va} ana Məloko ahay. | \gll ta-ndalaj ta-l=ala tɪ-ɮɪg-ɛ \textbf{va} ana Mʊlɔkʷɔ=ahaj | \gls 3P-PRG 3P-go=to 3P-throw-CL body DAT Moloko=Pl | \glt ‘They were coming and fighting with the Molokos.’ (lit. they were coming they threw body to Molokos)
Content 4: \gsrc Yam abah. | \gll jam à-bax | \gls water 3S+PFV-pour | \glt ‘Water poured.’
Content 5: \gsrc Mahay ápay. | \gll mahaj á-p-aj | \gls door 3S+IFV-open-CL | \glt ‘The door opens.’

Knowledge Point: Note that there are Moloko idioms that employ body parts with the verb g-e ‘do.' To get angry is to ‘do heart’ \REF{ex:9:50}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ege ɓərav. | \gll ɛ-g-ɛ ɓərav | \gls 3S-do-CL heart | \glt ‘He/she is angry.’ (lit. he/she does heart)

Knowledge Point: The idiom for ‘think’ is literally ‘do brain’ \REF{ex:9:51}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ge endeɓ! | \gll g-ɛ ɛndɛɓ | \gls do[twoS.IMP]-CL brain | \glt ‘Think!’ (lit. do brain)

Subsection: elé ‘eye’\label{sec:9.3.1\label{sec:9.3.1.1
Knowledge Point: The body-part noun elé ‘eye’ collocates with some verbs to lexicalise the engagement of the eyes and reduce the focus on what is seen. This body-part word is used in its full form. For example, the verb mənjar normally means ‘see’ (see \tabref{tab:76}). With the incorporation of elé (\ref{ex:9:52}-- \ref{ex:9:53}), the verb plus body-part construction has a more active experiential meaning in that the subject of the clause (Mala) is looking around attentively. Since there can be no direct object, there is no explicit referential object as stimulus -- the speaker is vague about what exactly Mala will look at.
Content 1: \gsrc Mala amənjar \textbf{elé.} | \gll Mala a-mənzar \textbf{ɛlɛ} | \gls Mala 3S-see eye | \glt ‘Mala looks around attentively.’
Content 2: \gsrc Mala olo aməmənzəre \textbf{elé} a ləhe. | \gll Mala ɔ-lɔ amɪ-mɪnʒɪrɛ \textbf{ɛlɛ} a lɪhɛ | \gls Mala 3S-go DEP-see eye at bush | \glt ‘Mala went to see his fields.’ (lit. Mala went to see in the bush)

Subsection: elé ‘eye’\label{sec:9.3.1\label{sec:9.3.1.1
Knowledge Point: With the verb har ‘carry’ \REF{ex:9:54}, the addition of elé also gives an entirely new lexical item -- expressing the idea of looking around intensively or studying every square inch (see \tabref{tab:76}.).
Content 1: \gsrc Nolo nahar \textbf{elé} a gəvah əwla ava jəyga. | \gll nɔ-lɔ na-har \textbf{ɛlɛ} a gəvax=uwla ava dzijga | \gls oneS-go oneS-carry eye at field=oneS.POSS in all | \glt ‘I go [and] look around my whole field.’ (lit. I carry eye in my field all)

Subsection: sləmay ‘ear’\label{sec:9.3.2\label{sec:9.3.1.2
Knowledge Point: For example, the normal lexical meaning of the verb cen is ‘hear’ or ‘understand’ \REF{ex:9:55} and the verb is bitransitive (see \sectref{sec:9.2.4}). The incorporation of the body-part sləmay ‘ear’ gives a much more active or intensive idea -- not just hear and understand someone, but also listen to them or obey them \REF{ex:9:56}. The focus is on the fact that the person is benefitting from using his ears to intently listen, rather than on the person speaking or the content of their message.
Content 1: \gsrc Mana écen bay. | \gll Mana \'{ɛ}-tʃɛŋ baj | \gls Mana 3S+IFV-hear NEG | \glt ‘Mana is deaf/doesn’t understand.’
Content 2: \gsrc Mana écen \textbf{sləmay} bay. | \gll Mana \'{ɛ}-tʃɛŋ \textbf{ɬəmaj} baj | \gls Mana 3S+IFV-hear ear NEG | \glt ‘Mana is deaf/disobedient.’

Subsection: ma ‘mouth’\label{sec:9.3.3\label{sec:9.3.1.3
Knowledge Point: The ‘body-part’ noun ma ‘mouth’ (which also means ‘word’ and ‘language’) collocates with some speech verbs. It is found in its full form in the verb plus body-part constructions. Example \REF{ex:9:57} shows the verb hay ‘say’ with the body-part noun ma ‘mouth.’
Content 1: \gsrc Tahok ma. | \gll ta-h=ɔkʷ ma | \gls 3P-tell=twoS.IO mouth | \glt ‘You are being greeted.’ (lit. they are telling word to you)

Subsection: va ‘body’\label{sec:9.3.4\label{sec:9.3.1.4
Knowledge Point: The first reduced form of hərva ‘body’ is va.\footnote{Note that there are three homophones of va which one must take care to distinguish: [=va] ‘perfect,’ [va] ‘body,’ and [ava] ‘in’. They all can occur immediately following the verb stem.} This body-part is used for forming reciprocals with plural subjects of a few verbs in a context of killing and loving (zləge ‘throw’ \ref{ex:9:58}--\ref{ex:9:59}, kaɗ ‘kill by clubbing’ \ref{ex:9:60}, and ndaɗay ‘need,’ \ref{ex:9:61}). The body-part va indicates that the plural subjects are performing the actions against one another.
Content 1: \gsrc Tandalay talala təzləgə \textbf{va} ana Məloko ahay. | \gll ta-nd=alaj ta-l =ala tɪ-ɮɪg-ɛ \textbf{va} ana Mʊlɔkʷɔ=ahaj | \gls 3P-PRG=away 3P-go =to 3P-throw-CL body DAT Moloko=Pl | \glt ‘They were coming and fighting with the Molokos.’ (lit. they were coming they threw body to Molokos)
Content 3: \gsrc Takaɗ \textbf{va}. | \gll ta-kaɗ \textbf{va} | \gls 3P-kill body | \glt ‘They kill each other.’ (lit. they kill.by.clubbing body)
Content 4: \gsrc Kondoɗom \textbf{va} a \textbf{va} ava. | \gll kɔ-ndɔɗ-ɔm \textbf{va} a \textbf{va} ava | \gls twoP-need-twoP body at body in | \glt ‘Love one another.’ (lit. need body in the body)

Subsection: va ‘body’\label{sec:9.3.4\label{sec:9.3.1.4
Knowledge Point: The body-part va ‘body’ occurs twice in the clause expressing the reciprocal idea of loving one another in \REF{ex:9:61} -- as incorporated noun and also as the noun phrase within an adpositional phrase (va is bolded in the example).
Content 1: \gsrc Kondoɗom \textbf{va} a \textbf{va} ava. | \gll kɔ-ndɔɗ-ɔm \textbf{va} a \textbf{va} ava | \gls twoP-need-twoP body at body in | \glt ‘Love one another.’ (lit. need body in the body)

Subsection: va ‘body’\label{sec:9.3.4\label{sec:9.3.1.4
Knowledge Point: The verb zaɗ ‘take’ also can incorporate the body-part va ‘body.’ The normal lexical meaning of the verb zaɗ is ‘take’ but the combination zaɗ va (\ref{ex:9:62} and \ref{ex:9:63}) carries the idea of ‘resemble’ or ‘look like’ and occurs with singular as well as plural subjects. With a plural subject \REF{ex:9:63}, the clause has a reciprocal idea -- the subjects resemble each other.
Content 1: \gsrc Məlama ango azaɗ \textbf{va} nə nok. | \gll məlama=aŋgʷɔ a-zaɗ \textbf{va} nə nɔkʷ | \gls sibling=twoS.POSS 3S-take body with twoS | \glt ‘Your sibling resembles you.’ (lit. your sibling takes body with you)
Content 2: \gsrc Məlama ango ahay jəyga tazaɗ \textbf{va}. | \gll məlama=aŋgʷɔ=ahaj dʒijga ta-zaɗ \textbf{va} | \gls sibling=twoS.POSS=Pl all 3P-take body | \glt ‘All your siblings look alike.’ (lit. siblings take [each other’s] body)
Content 3: \gsrc Məlama ango ahay jəyga tazaɗ \textbf{va}. | \gll məlama=aŋgʷɔ=ahaj dʒijga ta-zaɗ \textbf{va} | \gls sibling=twoS.POSS=Pl all 3P-take body | \glt ‘All your siblings look alike.’ (lit. siblings take [each other’s] body)

Subsection: va ‘body’\label{sec:9.3.4\label{sec:9.3.1.4
Knowledge Point: The body part va can also collocate with other verbs. For example \textit{e{}mbesen} means ‘he/she breathes,’ but \textit{e{}mbesen} va means ‘he/she is resting’ \REF{ex:9:64}.
Content 1: \gsrc Embesen va kə cəveɗ aka. | \gll ɛ-mbɛʃɛŋ va kə tʃɪvɛɗ aka | \gls 3S-breathe body on road on | \glt ‘He rests enroute [to somewhere].’

Subsection: har ‘body’\label{sec:9.3.5\label{sec:9.3.1.5
Knowledge Point: A second reduced form of hərva, har ‘body,’ demonstrates another non-pro\-duc\-tive collocation with some verbs. With the verb wəɗakay, which normally means ‘divide,’ the incorporation of har gives a new lexical meaning containing the idea of the participants dispersing (lit. a reflexive idea of ‘dividing themselves up’ \ref{ex:9:65}).
Content 1: Not found

Subsection: har ‘body’\label{sec:9.3.5\label{sec:9.3.1.5
Knowledge Point: With the verb gas which normally means ‘catch,’ har gives the lexical idea of pleasing, which is located at the indirect object \REF{ex:9:66}.
Content 1: Not found

Section: Clauses with zero grammatical arguments\label{sec:9.4\is{Transitivity!Clauses with zero transitivity|(
Knowledge Point: (\sectref{sec:3.6.3}). See also zero transitivity in nominalised forms, \sectref{sec:8.2.3}.} Nominalised and dependent verb forms are not inflected for subject (see Sections \ref{sec:7.6} and \ref{sec:7.7}, respectively). When they also carry no \DO or \IO pronominal, the clause has zero transitivity. The use of verb forms with no grammatical relations has a discourse function to temporarily take participants out of sight. In the Disobedient Girl story peak episode S. 22 \REF{ex:9:67}, the dependent verb aməhaya ‘grinding,’ is unconjugated for subject, direct object, and indirect object. The effect is to keep the participants out of sight as the events unfold and increase vividness as the audience is drawn into the story. All the audience hears is the sound of grinding. The millet is expanding, filling the room and the disobedient girl is lost inside it as she is being suffocated by the millet.
Content 1: Not found

Section: Clauses with zero grammatical arguments\label{sec:9.4\is{Transitivity!Clauses with zero transitivity|(
Knowledge Point: Likewise in line S. 15 of the Snake story \REF{ex:9:68}, the nominalised form of the verb ‘to penetrate’ occurs with neither \DO nor indirect object pronominals. The climactic moment when the storyteller spears the snake is in a clause with zero transitivity.\is{Focus and prominence!Discourse peak} Participants are out of sight in the discourse.
Content 1: Not found
